newsitem.title: USA: Initial report issued on impact of Illinois gaming.
newsitem.headline: Initial report issued on impact of Illinois gaming.

text.p: An initial report released Wednesday indicated that riverboat casinos in Illinois had an economic and fiscal impact of an estimated $2.2 billion between 1991 and 1995.
The report, issued by the Illinois Gaming Commission, said that in 1995 alone the 10 floating casinos in the state had a direct economic impact of an estimated $763 million.
As for wagering and admissions taxes, the report said that casinos paid $749.3 million in those taxes during the 1991-95 time period, with tax collections reaching nearly $293 million in 1995 alone.

However, the report by the state agency pointed out that an upward trend in the annual level of direct economic impact ended in 1995 "largely as a result of diminished capital outlays and a relatively static revenue base" for the 10 casinos.
Indirect impact from the casinos, on the other hand, has fallen short of expectations, the report said. Specifically, anticipated increases in local retail trade and tourism have not materialized.
The report said that while revenues generated by casino gaming have exceeded expectations made in 1990, some predictions have not come true.
"It is evident that additional research is nedded before the experience with riverboat casino gaming can be declared an economic plus or minus for Illinois," the report said.
